sentence: Why did the mortgage broker go out of business? ...because he lost interest.
explanation: Interest can refer to a financial gain or benefit and also to a mental engagement or concern about something.
first_new_sentence: The bank offers a high interest rate on savings accounts.
second_new_sentence: Her interest in environmental issues grew as she learned more about climate change.

sentence: What do you call five black cars that all crash into each other? a three car pile-up.
explanation: Car refers to a vehicle and colloquially can refer to a physical person (used in a joking manner).
first_new_sentence: I drove my car to work today.
second_new_sentence: The car at the party was the life of the event.

sentence: What does the average drummer get on an iq test? drool.
explanation: Drool can mean saliva that flows from the mouth and can also refer to someone being excessively droopy/infatuated
first_new_sentence: The dog started to drool when it saw the treat.
second_new_sentence: He couldnt help but drool over the beautiful painting in the gallery.

sentence: This output captures jokes based on words with two meanings and provides serious sentences for each meaning.
